Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: I balanced the package on my hip as I rang the doorbell, glancing at my phone. My mother’s text glowed on the screen: “Don’t forget, dinner at 6. Grandma expects you to help with the dumplings.” It was Lunar New Year, and I knew how much it meant to my family that I be there, hands dusted with flour, laughing with my cousins. But here I was, in my delivery uniform, waiting for a customer to answer the door. The package was worth enough that I needed a signature, and my supervisor had reminded me—no shortcuts, no missed confirmations. I checked the time. If the customer didn’t come soon, I’d be late for dinner, disappointing my family and missing the tradition I’d grown up with. But if I left the package or skipped the signature, I’d risk my job. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: the warmth of family, the pride in my work. The door remained closed, and I stood on the porch, torn between two worlds, feeling the pressure of both roles pressing in on me.
